üëç 

back story: 0.9.0.1 fixes some critical bugs in the new consumer, which we use in this extension.

We hit a nasty bug where problems talking to a Kafka broker would cause the Kafka consumer to go into an infinite loop which wouldn't exit even when the Kafka broker came back. This effectively brought down the supervisor. The fix was introduced in 0.9.0.1 as part of this issue: https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2880
üëç
üëç
Fixed by https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3110/files
üëç

I've made hive storage handler via approch (1). Because current hive does not provide opportunity to change DAG in planning stage(which is possible in Spark), I've used select query with filters and projections. The bottom line is that it was too slow. If hive takes 100msec for processing n rows, historical node can make them in less than 50msec. But json serde + network takes 100~300msec which ruins overall performance. it's sub second for single query but retrieving lot's of rows via hundreds of queries(1G tez task throws OOM for 3000+ rows) was not the right way to be done. I have some ideas to improve this but it's low priority job and seemed not be done in a month or two.

ps. But still my colleagues like it because simple select SQL is not ran on MR or TEZ, which means the result is returned in sub-second, of course. Some uses it loading druid datasource into hive table by using CTAS or insert query.
good! üëç

@navis we are rewriting groupBy right now: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2998

@navis that sounds great, is that public? Have you looked into making groupBy queries (when appropriate) in addition to select? That should really take advantage of Druid's abilities better, and limit serde/network traffic.

btw, what were the ideas you had to improve the performance of "select"? I'm curious because IMO improving "select" and "groupBy" are both pretty valuable, they are used a lot by users but not very optimized compared to "timeseries" and "topN". I did some work on groupBy in #2998 but have not looked at select at all yet.
#2908, #3091 also seems related.

Old readers cannot read the new format, right? In that case I'd prefer writers to use the old format by default, otherwise people can't have control over when they migrate (they might want to not switch right away to preserve ability to roll back or to keep using some older tools that read segments directly).

I just discovered I had been packaging the mysql metadata .9.0 extension with druid .9.1. Fixing that fixed another weird state problem I was seeing, so I'm thinking we can probably close this one out. I'll re-open if I see the problem again post-fix. While that's my fault, a sanity check requiring extension versions to match the server they're being loaded into might be cool. Anyways, Thanks everyone!

@gianm I mean http://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/sql-programming-guide.html#dataframes data frames. But yes, there already seems preference to move to data sets now as well (I had heard of those but forgot what they were called). Anyways, the point is I would avoid mentioning RDDs directly and simply refer to them as generic distributed data.

https://github.com/RoaringBitmap/RoaringBitmap/blob/master/CHANGELOG
@gianm because noone submitted a thing to bytebuffer-collections
I don't know what the compatibility between 0.5.x and 0.6.x is. Maybe @lemire can comment if there would be any unexpected things happen to things created with 0.5.x roaring if we updated to 0.6.x?
Filed https://github.com/metamx/bytebuffer-collections/pull/35

@drcrallen 

The API and the file format should be considered stable. We are mostly just optimizing performance, reducing memory usage and adding (small) features. Upgrading to the latest version should not be an issue and you should expect performance and memory-usage gains.

If any issue should arise (unlikely), we are there to help.

It is recommended to update to version 0.6 of RoaringBitmap _except_ if you need Java 6 support. We deliberately stopped testing Java 6 with version 0.6. But if anyone is using Druid with Java 6, they have other problems, presumably...

> But if anyone is using Druid with Java 6, they have other problems, presumably...

Yes, like "rejected jars" kind of problems. Thanks!

Would it be better to make a rule on dimension name? (no special characters, not slash, etc.)
Merging this as it only impacts the scripts and not any actual code so travis isn't actually testing anything related to these changes.

@navis there's a lot of effort to let dimension _values_ be arbitrary. It makes sense to me to allow as much as is reasonable in the dimension naming. I _would_ just set the file names to be uuid's but that requires a bunch more refactoring to get right.

üëç
@nishantmonu51 after this fix do integration tests all pass?

It looks like SearchBinaryFn doesn't check if each incoming searchHit has a null count or not. It looks like it assumes that if one searchHit has a count, then they all will (it will blindly + them together without null checks). So it'll probably NPE.

That could cause issues with network caches, since older cached results will have null counts, which may cause merging on either historicals or broker to NPE.

not sure of the best way to fix this, perhaps change the cache key?

[edited to remove reference to rolling updates ‚Äì¬†that's fine as long as brokers are updated last, which they usually are]

@fjy: yeah the integration tests pass after this fix. 
@gianm:  updated the merge function to handle NPE & updated cache key.

I tried this myself, I believe the issue you noticed is due to not running `bin/init` ‚Äì¬†I saw similar issues when I didn't run it, but things were OK when I did. Another note: as written, those "x.sh" scripts do not actually work with the quickstart, because they hardcode "conf" rather than having a switch between "conf" and "conf-quickstart" (not clear if this is intentional).

I think these are ok for 0.9.1 because,
- the quickstart calls out that running `bin/init` is something one should do
- the quickstart (or any of the docs) never mention the "x.sh" scripts

So I am inclined to move this to 0.9.2, as an improvement rather than a bug fix.
